Award.AwardTitle: Preparing Responsive Educators using Place-Based Authentic Research in Earth Systems (PREPARES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project expands, implements and conducts research on a previously developed framework for providing indigenous students with the workforce skills and knowledge needed for future Earth system science careers. The framework proven effective for Inupiat students during the NSF/ITEST-funded Arctic Climate Modeling Program (ESI-0525277) will be scaled up to develop culturally responsive STEM instruction for 1500 Yup'ik and Native Hawaiian middle school students and their 60 teachers. The multifaceted scale-up project includes: a broader research setting, more school districts, diverse indigenous cultures, additional STEM workforce practices, and a broader expert pool. The goal of the scale-up is to answer the research question, "Under what circumstances are the PREPARES framework for offering culturally responsive STEM instruction effective in increasing indigenous student disposition toward participating in future Earth system science careers?" Student objectives include assessing three indicators of student disposition toward STEM careers: (a) STEM academic achievement, (b) interest in STEM careers, and (c) STEM workforce skill readiness. Teacher objectives related to program sustainability include increasing educator STEM content knowledge and pedagogical strategies aligned with STEM workforce practices. Research by randomized controlled trial will determine framework transferability and identify circumstances and steps needed to expand its adoption to a broader array of U.S. schools.

This project is a professional development program for non-Native teachers of indigenous students. The project offers training that helps teachers provide culturally responsive science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) instruction in areas, such as Alaska and Hawaii, that support strong indigenous populations, but where the vast majority of teachers are non-Native. The research component will gather data and information that will advance the understanding of a framework for broadening indigenous participation in STEM study and careers. The activity targets middle school students because research indicates that middle school is a time when engagement in STEM studies begins to decline. Encouraging indigenous students to view completing high school as a step toward STEM careers is important because Native students compose a high percentage of the dropout population in Alaska and Hawaii. Culturally responsive STEM training is needed because many STEM teachers enter their preparation programs with little or no inter-cultural experience and with beliefs and assumptions that undermine the goal of providing an equal education for all students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preparing Responsive Educators Using Place-based Authentic Research in Earth Systems (PREPARES)

Indigenous students in Alaska and Hawaii score below average on science and mathematics achievement tests. PREPARES evaluated an approach to bridge the cultural and experiential differences between indigenous students and non-indigenous teachers and to make instruction meaningful to students by using place-based, culturally responsive, and community-relevant instruction. The goal was for middle school students to become more knowledgeable about the effects of climate change and about strategies for adapting to these effects, to develop skills that can be applied in future science and mathematics classes, and to form more positive dispositions toward pursuing future science courses and STEM-related careers.

The project conducted teacher professional development, published supplemental instructional materials to facilitate the transfer of teacher training into classroom instruction, and designed and implemented online interaction tools that enabled teachers and students in isolated settings to communicate with one another. Scientists, community leaders, business partners, teachers, school administrators, students, and parents were vital sounding boards and contributors throughout the project.

Four units of instruction specific to Alaska and four specific to Hawaii were developed. Each unit was related to a climate change problem or issue identified by the community. Teachers were prepared to use the materials and the three-prong instructional approach in face-to-face meetings and through online instruction. Fidelity of curriculum implementation was monitored through regular teacher reports, individual interactions between teachers and PREPARES personnel, and timeliness of teachers’ submitting unit test results.

Instructional tools included hand-on activities and lessons, readings specific to the content, videos of local STEM professionals working on area climate issues, online interactions among Alaskan and Hawaiian students, and classroom discussions prompted by PREPARES critical thinking exercises. Students were evaluated at the end of each unit to assess their understanding of geophysical content, their ability to use science process skills, and their knowledge of related STEM careers. Evaluation tools included content tests, student surveys, student interviews, and teacher interviews.

A Randomized Control study with treatment and control group comparison was used to determine the impact of the PREPARES program. Classes of students within matched schools were randomly assigned to a treatment or a control group. Students in both groups were administered a content test that covered relevant STEM concepts and skills and their understanding of related science careers. At the end of the program, students representing both groups were interviewed to determine their career interests. Teachers were interviewed in focus groups to determine their perceptions of student achievement, engagement, and interests in pursuing future science classes and careers.

The test evaluating student understanding of science concepts shows consistent statistically significant differences between students who participated in PREPARES and students in the control groups. Across all four tests, the average score for Alaskan Treatment Group students was 79% while the Control Group average score was 16%. For Hawaiian Treatment Group students, the average across all four tests was 73% and the Control group average score was 10%.

Students in the PREPARES group were more knowledgeable about science-related careers than those in the control group. Survey responses showed they were able to name more STEM careers, to describe them, and to tell how that career could benefit their home communities. Further evidence for the difference in knowledge of and interest in STEM careers between students who experienced PREPARES and students in the control group was the variety and types of careers students identified. Overall, students participating in PREPARES named 33 different careers, 97% of which were STEM related. Control group students names 34 different careers but only 32% were STEM related. Clearly, students who experienced the PREPARES curriculum were more aware of and more disposed toward STEM-related careers.

PREPARES is a potentially transformative framework for offering culturally responsive STEM instruction. Previously, the approach was shown to significantly increase Inupiat indigenous student STEM content knowledge and disposition toward STEM careers. This study demonstrated that similar results are found when the approach is scaled-up and used with students from different cultural backgrounds (Yupik and Native Hawaiian) and focused on different content.

The project advanced understanding of how to encourage indigenous participation in STEM study and careers. The project served middle school students and their teachers from two states and two indigenous cultures: Yup'ik students from the Lower Yukon Kuskokwim Delta in Alaska, and Native Hawaiian students from the Big Island of Hawaii. Success with these two indigenous groups suggests that the PREPARES framework may be transferable to other indigenous populations across the nation.
